div1.p: This is the letter it has take ten years to be able to write--THE MANUSCRIPT IS IN THE MAIL!!!! I have sent back the contract to Mr. Nicoll--signed, and Bower is mailing the Xerox copy of the book to you this morning. It's the security copy; I wanted to have a duplicate in case something wild happened to the mailed one; Bower sent it by registered mail, so accident is not likely, but it's always wise to have more than one copy. The full set of footnotes are there--in fact, it's exactly what the publisher received. I thought you should see it all together in better type than I can produce. Now we'll hope Mr. Nicoll likes it.

I'm sorry Robin is in the big whirlwind. Our Charles was over there for a year and we feel fortunate that he got back intact. I'm sure Robin will too; there's a pattern. Stewart goes into active service this fall, but he probably will not be sent right overseas; Did I tell you--yes, I did--he is going to be a father, and we will all feel better if he can be somewhere that Susan can also go.

I wrote Mr. Nicoll to let me know when the new edition of When the Tree Flowered came out; I want a copy of it myself, and I know several people here who want a copy too. I have a tremendous affection for that book, partly because the tone is so perfectly a reflection of you, the music fo what happens with light grace notes through the deep and sober strains.

So now we can really celebrate when I come out this summer. Let's have a select "We Did It!" pary about our book--very exclusive guest list and congratulations all round. It's your book really; you lived it.
Much love, and take care of yourself. Do just what Jacquot tells you, and save your energy for rejoicements this summer.
